skill.name: doc-coauthoring
skill.description: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to write documentation, proposals, technical specs, decision docs, or similar structured content. This workflow helps users efficiently transfer context, refine content through iteration, and verify the doc works for readers. Trigger when user mentions writing docs, creating proposals, drafting specs, or similar documentation tasks.
skill.summary: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to wri...

security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill containing only documentation workflow guidance with no code execution, external requests, or sensitive operations. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: A structured three-stage workflow that guides you through creating high-quality documentation by gathering context, iteratively refining content, and testing with a fresh perspective to catch blind spots before sharing.
actual_capabilities: Guides through three-stage documentation creation: Context Gathering, Refinement & Structure, and Reader Testing
Asks clarifying questions to extract comprehensive context from users
Supports integration with Slack, Teams, Google Drive, SharePoint via MCP connectors to pull in context
Brainstorms 5-20 content options per section for user curation
Builds documents section-by-section through iterative refinement
Uses artifacts or files to maintain document scaffold during creation
Tests document with fresh Claude instance to verify clarity for readers
Adapts to various document types: technical specs, decision docs, proposals, RFCs, PRDs
Handles both template-based and freeform document creation
Makes surgical edits using str_replace to avoid reprinting entire documents
limitations: Requires substantial user engagement throughout the three-stage process
Reader testing with sub-agents only available in Claude Code environment
Cannot directly edit shared documents - provides content for user to paste
Effectiveness depends on user's ability to provide comprehensive context upfront
May feel slower than freeform writing for users who prefer unstructured approaches

use_cases.title: Technical Specification Writing
use_cases.description: Create comprehensive technical specs with architecture decisions, implementation details, and trade-off analysis using structured brainstorming and reader testing

use_cases.title: Decision Document Creation
use_cases.description: Draft decision docs that clearly communicate choices, alternatives considered, and rationale while ensuring stakeholders understand the context
use_cases.target_user: Product managers, engineering managers, technical decision-makers

use_cases.title: Proposal Development
use_cases.description: Build project proposals that effectively communicate impact, approach, and resource needs through iterative refinement and gap analysis
use_cases.target_user: Project managers, team leads, business strategists

use_cases.title: RFC Authoring
use_cases.description: Create Request for Comments documents that clearly present problems, proposed solutions, and invite meaningful feedback from reviewers

use_cases.title: Product Requirements Documentation
use_cases.description: Develop PRDs that comprehensively capture user needs, success metrics, and implementation constraints through structured context gathering

prompt_templates.title: Start a Technical Spec
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to write a technical spec for [project/feature name]. I want to document [main technical decision or approach].
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginning a new technical specification document

prompt_templates.title: Create a Decision Doc
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a decision doc about [decision topic]. The main stakeholders are [audience] and I need to explain why we're choosing [approach].
prompt_templates.scenario: Documenting an important technical or business decision

prompt_templates.title: Draft a Project Proposal
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to write a proposal for [project name]. The goal is to [desired impact] for [target audience].
prompt_templates.scenario: Proposing a new project or initiative

prompt_templates.title: Write an RFC
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to draft an RFC for [feature/change]. I want feedback on [specific aspects].
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a Request for Comments document

output_examples.input: I need to write a technical spec for migrating our database from PostgreSQL to MongoDB.
output_examples.output: The skill guides through: (1) Context gathering - asking about current architecture, migration drivers, team expertise, timeline, and stakeholder concerns; (2) Section-by-section drafting of background, proposed approach, migration strategy, rollback plan, and success metrics with brainstorming and curation for each; (3) Reader testing with fresh Claude to verify the spec is clear to engineers unfamiliar with the project.

output_examples.input: Help me create a decision doc about choosing between React and Vue for our new frontend.
output_examples.output: The skill systematically: (1) Gathers context about team skills, project requirements, existing tech stack, and evaluation criteria; (2) Structures sections for problem statement, options evaluated, decision rationale, trade-offs, and implementation plan; (3) Brainstorms 10-15 points per section for user curation; (4) Tests the final doc with Reader Claude to ensure decision reasoning is clear.

best_practices: Provide comprehensive context upfront during Stage 1 - dump everything you know about the project, stakeholders, constraints, and background
Use numbered shorthand when responding to questions (e.g., '1: yes, 2: no, 3: see #channel-name') for efficiency
Start with sections that have the most unknowns rather than writing sequentially
Give specific feedback during refinement (e.g., 'Make paragraph 3 more concise') rather than general comments
Enable MCP connectors for Slack, Teams, or document storage to allow direct context pulling
Complete Reader Testing stage even if document feels done - it catches blind spots authors miss
Use appendices for depth without bloating main sections
Link to relevant Slack threads, docs, or this conversation in appendices for future reader context
anti_patterns: Skipping context gathering and jumping straight to drafting - leads to multiple revision rounds later
Editing the document directly instead of indicating what to change - prevents the skill from learning your style
Answering brainstorming questions with vague responses like 'looks good' instead of numbered selections
Skipping Reader Testing because the doc 'seems clear' - authors have context bias
Writing all sections sequentially without focusing on high-uncertainty areas first
Providing minimal context and expecting the skill to fill in gaps with generic content

faq.question: How long does this workflow take compared to writing freeform?
faq.answer: The workflow takes longer upfront but typically results in fewer revision rounds after sharing. Most users complete documents in 1-2 focused sessions. You can always switch to freeform if the structure feels too constraining.

faq.question: Can I use this for shorter documents like emails or brief updates?
faq.answer: This workflow is optimized for substantial documentation (specs, proposals, decision docs). For shorter content, the overhead may not be worth it - freeform writing is likely more efficient.

faq.question: What if I don't have access to sub-agents for Reader Testing?
faq.answer: The skill provides manual testing instructions - you'll open a fresh Claude conversation at claude.ai, paste the document, and ask the predicted reader questions yourself. It's slightly more work but equally effective.

faq.question: Do I need to have a template before starting?
faq.answer: No, templates are optional. If you have one, the skill will use it. If not, it will suggest appropriate sections based on your document type (spec, proposal, RFC, etc.).

faq.question: Can I skip stages or jump around?
faq.answer: Yes, you have full agency to adjust the process. You can skip stages, work freeform, or request specific modifications. The skill will ask for confirmation before major deviations.

faq.question: How do MCP integrations help with this workflow?
faq.answer: MCP connectors (Slack, Teams, Google Drive, SharePoint) let the skill directly read team channels, shared documents, and related context instead of requiring you to copy-paste everything. This makes context gathering much faster.
